abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.simpara: To provide the fundamentals of the theory of stress and strain analysis. These principles will be used to derive generalized elastic constitutive relations in engineering materials. Prediction of failure of materials as well yielding and failure criteria are incorporated. The course provide the background to deal with advanced topics of solid mechanics for the analysis of industrial structural design problems found in applied engineering. Keywords: Stress, strain, stress-strain relationships, strain energy, failure theories, curved beams, unsymmetrical bending, shear center, torsion of noncircular sections, energy principles, Castigliano’s theorem, inelastic behavior

section.title: Course Introduction
section.simpara: We will be looking at 3 underlying principles throughout this course:

listitem.simpara: Equilibrium Equations: all forces balanced
Mechanical Behavior (Constitutive Equations): use stress-strain and force relationships that satisfy certain materials
Geometry of Deformation (Compatibility of Equations): information throughout the body must fit together with other portions of the body

important.title: Final Exam
important.simpara: Final exam for graduate students is open notes.

section.simpara: Dr. Lugo will be assigning the Final Project based on Teams. Design of Final Project should be validated with experiment.

section.title: Stress Analysis of a State of Plane Stress

figure.title: Usually we design for the yield stress of a material because we like linear. Failure depends on your criterion.

formalpara.title: Allowable Stress and Factor of Safety
formalpara.para: For example, a home is a multi-physics problem with many design contraints and variables to accomplish the objectives and satisfy the goals that allow one to live in the home.

section.simpara: The nuclear industry uses a factor of safety, FOS = 5FOS = 5.

formalpara.title: Internal Forces
formalpara.para: The design of a structure or a mechanical member requires to know the loading acting within the member.

listitem.simpara: Forces acting within a plane when a body is "cut" across some section.

Normal forces attempt to elongate or compress the body with a force normal to the surface wherein the force acts. \sum_{z} = 0\sum_{z} = 0, \int dN = \sigma dA \implies \sigma = \frac{F}{A}\int dN = \sigma dA \implies \sigma = \frac{F}{A}

Shear forces acts in-plane to cause bodies to slide past each other. \tau = \frac{V}{A} = \frac{T\rho}{J}\tau = \frac{V}{A} = \frac{T\rho}{J}, where \tau_{max} = \frac{Tr}{J}\tau_{max} = \frac{Tr}{J} and \tau_{rect} = \frac{VQ}{It}\tau_{rect} = \frac{VQ}{It}, Q = A'\bar{y}' \implies (\tau_{rect})_{max} = \frac{3V}{2A}Q = A'\bar{y}' \implies (\tau_{rect})_{max} = \frac{3V}{2A}

Torsional moments or torques tend to twist the body aboust some axis perpendicular to the area. T = \int \rho dFT = \int \rho dF, where if \tau = \frac{dF}{dA} \rightarrow dF = \tau dA \implies T = \int\rho\tau dA\tau = \frac{dF}{dA} \rightarrow dF = \tau dA \implies T = \int\rho\tau dA

Bending moments tend to bend the body about an axis within some plane of area in the body. \sigma_{flexure} = \frac{My}{I}\sigma_{flexure} = \frac{My}{I}, where \sigma_{max} = Mc}{I}\sigma_{max} = Mc}{I}

figure.title: Types of internal forces visualized.

listitem.simpara: the representative way in which force is distributed throughout a body.
When twisted, the cross-section of a torqued body is assumed to remain plane and the angle of twist is rather small.
Here, the cross-section, and consuqeunt loadings, are symmetric.
Generally thought to act independent of bending; although, this is not actually the case in many conditions. The distribution of this stress along a cross-section is parabolic.

formalpara.title: General State of Stress
formalpara.para: The "stress state" of a point is defined by the stress components acting on this sides of a differential volume that encloses the point.

listitem.simpara: The faces of the element are designated by the directions of their normal.
The single subscript on the normal stress indicates the face on which it acts.

figure.title: The stresses are acting on one plane. In this state, two faces are of stress.

section.simpara: These lead to principal stresses which are 180^{\circ}180^{\circ} apart:

figure.title: Mohr’s Circle is a common way to represent these transformation equations. The center point, C = (\sigma, \tau) = (\sigma_{avg}, 0)C = (\sigma, \tau) = (\sigma_{avg}, 0) and the radius, R = \sqrt{[ \frac{\sigma_{x} - \sigma_{y}}{2} ]^{2} + \tau_{xy}^{2}}R = \sqrt{[ \frac{\sigma_{x} - \sigma_{y}}{2} ]^{2} + \tau_{xy}^{2}}.

equation.alt: \begin{split} \sum F_{x} = 0 := A_{x} &= 0 \\\ \implies A_{x} &= 0 \\\ \sum \mathcal{M}_{A} = 0 := N_{F}*r_{A-N} - W*r_{A-W} &= 0 \\\ N_{F}*850 - 200*9.81*1150 &= 0 \\\ \implies N_{f} &= 2654.47~N \\\ \sum F_{y} = 0 := A_{y} + N_{F} - W &= 0 \\\ \implies A_{y} &= asdf~MPa \end{split}
equation.mathphrase: \begin{split} \sum F_{x} = 0 := A_{x} &= 0 \\\ \implies A_{x} &= 0 \\\ \sum \mathcal{M}_{A} = 0 := N_{F}*r_{A-N} - W*r_{A-W} &= 0 \\\ N_{F}*850 - 200*9.81*1150 &= 0 \\\ \implies N_{f} &= 2654.47~N \\\ \sum F_{y} = 0 := A_{y} + N_{F} - W &= 0 \\\ \implies A_{y} &= asdf~MPa \end{split}

The factor of safety, FOS = \frac{\sigma_{y}}{\sigma_{CD}} = \frac{220 MPa}{4.96 MPa} = 44.35FOS = \frac{\sigma_{y}}{\sigma_{CD}} = \frac{220 MPa}{4.96 MPa} = 44.35 is well above the typical FOS = 2FOS = 2; therefore, this piston \bar{CD}\bar{CD} is over-designed.

blockquote.simpara: Mechanics of Materials is the study of internal forces of a body within a structure.

formalpara.title: Internal Forces
formalpara.para: If we cut a body/element along some plane, then we can look at the forces that act within that plane due to external loadings to observe how the material of the component itself reacts to those loadings. Moments cause the element to bend, and we assume the planes remain plane. Shear causes the faces of the element to pass laterally to other faces, and we assume that planes remain vertical. Normal stresses causes the element to change length, and we assume constant volume (Poisson’s Ratio).

section.title: Three Dimensional Stress Analysis and Equilibrium

figure.title: Consider an element of sides dxdx and dydy of some unit thickness. It is assumed that \sigma_{x}\sigma_{x}, \sigma_{y}\sigma_{y}, \tau_{xy}\tau_{xy}, and \tau_{yx}\tau_{yx} are functions of xx and yy. Assume that the xx and yy components of the body forces per unit volume, F_{x}F_{x} and F_{y}F_{y}.

section.simpara: In mechanics, there are 2 types of forces: external and internal loads. We often describe these as body forces and remote forces (). If we take the sum of the moments about the lower-left corner, then \sum M_{z} = 0 := (\frac{\partial\sigma_{y}}{\partial y}dxdy)\frac{dx}{2} - (\frac{\partial\sigma_{x}}{\partial x}dxdy)\frac{dy}{2} + (\tau_{xy} + \frac{\partial\tau_{xy}}{\partial x}dx)dxdy - (\tau_{yx} + \frac{\partial\tau_{yx}}{\partial y}dy)dxdy + F_{y}dxdy\frac{dx}{2} - F_{x}dxdy\frac{dy}{2} = 0\sum M_{z} = 0 := (\frac{\partial\sigma_{y}}{\partial y}dxdy)\frac{dx}{2} - (\frac{\partial\sigma_{x}}{\partial x}dxdy)\frac{dy}{2} + (\tau_{xy} + \frac{\partial\tau_{xy}}{\partial x}dx)dxdy - (\tau_{yx} + \frac{\partial\tau_{yx}}{\partial y}dy)dxdy + F_{y}dxdy\frac{dx}{2} - F_{x}dxdy\frac{dy}{2} = 0. This reduces to \tau_{xy} = \tau_{yx}\tau_{xy} = \tau_{yx}. Similarly, in 3 dimensions, the following can be found \tau_{yz} = \tau_{zy}\tau_{yz} = \tau_{zy} and \tau_{xz} = \tau_{zx}\tau_{xz} = \tau_{zx}. From sum of the xx forces: \sum F_{x} = 0 := (\sigma_{x} + \frac{\partial\sigma_{x}\tau_{x}}dx)dy - \sigma_{x}dy + (\tau_{xy} + \frac{\partial\tau_{xy}}{\partial y}dy)dx + \tau_{xy}dx - F_{x}dxdy = 0\sum F_{x} = 0 := (\sigma_{x} + \frac{\partial\sigma_{x}\tau_{x}}dx)dy - \sigma_{x}dy + (\tau_{xy} + \frac{\partial\tau_{xy}}{\partial y}dy)dx + \tau_{xy}dx - F_{x}dxdy = 0. This simplifies to: (\frac{\partial\sigma_{x}}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial\sigma_{x}}{\partial y} + F_{x})dxdy = 0(\frac{\partial\sigma_{x}}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial\sigma_{x}}{\partial y} + F_{x})dxdy = 0. Because dxdx and dydy are non-zero:
By expanding to 3 dimensions:

figure.title: The stress state of a point is defined by the stress components acting on the sides of a differential volume that encloses the point which requires 9 forces in total.

section.simpara: Often times, we use a matrix to represent these 9 forces: [\sigma_{ij}] = \[\tau_{ij}] = \mathbf{\tau}_{ij} = \bmatrix{\sigma_{x}, \tau_{xy}, \tau_{xz} \\ \tau_{yx}, \sigma_{y}, \tau_{yz} \\ \tau_{zx}, \tau_{zy}, \sigma_{z}}\bmatrix[\sigma_{ij}] = \[\tau_{ij}] = \mathbf{\tau}_{ij} = \bmatrix{\sigma_{x}, \tau_{xy}, \tau_{xz} \\ \tau_{yx}, \sigma_{y}, \tau_{yz} \\ \tau_{zx}, \tau_{zy}, \sigma_{z}}\bmatrix]. However, we must remember that this matrix is symmetric.

figure.title: The equations governing the transformation of the stress in 3D are obtained using a similar approach to that applied to the 2D case. Therefore, we can follow a similar manner to consider a tetrahedron isolated from a continuous medium subjected to a general state of stress.

section.simpara: The orientation of plane ABCABC is defined in terms of angles between a unit normal, nn to the plane and the xx, yy, and zz directions. The directions cosines associated with these angles are:

The equilibrium forces can be obtained after canceling the area, AA. The areas of perpendicular planes QABQAB, QACQAC, and QBCQBC can be expressed in terms of AA, the area of ABCABC and the direction cosines:
Using the stress tensor, we can represent these equilibrium equations by:
Using matrix notation:

figure.title: foo

textobject.phrase: stress equilibrium equations normal and shear 220120 140206 EST

section.simpara: The normal stress, \sigma\sigma is the projection of the vector, \vec{p}\vec{p} in the direction of \mathbf{n}\mathbf{n}.
The magnitude of the shear stress, \tau\tau on plane ABCABC can be computed by geometry:

figure.title: The variance of the stress with respect to surface orientation.

section.simpara: The transformation matrix is composed by the direction cosines: l_{1} = \cos(x', x), m_{1} = \cos(x', y)l_{1} = \cos(x', x), m_{1} = \cos(x', y), and so on. The complete set of direction cosines is:
In tensor notation: …​

figure.title: Using these transformation equations for stresses acting on a new axis, \vec{p} = [\tau_{ij}]\vec{n}\vec{p} = [\tau_{ij}]\vec{n} on an oblique plane in this new coordinate system becomes \vec{}' = [\tau_{ij}']\vec{n'}\vec{}' = [\tau_{ij}']\vec{n'}.

textobject.phrase: stress transformation in cartesian with new axes 220120 141529 EST

section.simpara: These vectors can be related by: \vec{p}' = \vec{T} \cdot \vec{p}\vec{p}' = \vec{T} \cdot \vec{p}. This can be combined with the transformed stress tensor into: [\tau_{ij}'[\tau_{ij}'\vec{n}' = \vec{T}[\tau_{ij}]\vec{n}]. The relationship between \vec{n}\vec{n} and \vec{n}'\vec{n}' can be obtained by the inversion of \vec{n}' = \vec{T}\vec{n}\vec{n}' = \vec{T}\vec{n} which is \vec{n} = \vec{T}^{T}\vec{n}'\vec{n} = \vec{T}^{T}\vec{n}'.
The book performs the same derivations with different notation. Ultimately, these two expressions are equivalent, but the book’s notation is longer and more expressive.

formalpara.title: Principal Stress in 3D
formalpara.para: Planes with zero shear stress are mutually perpendicular and have a (min)maximum which are called principal stresses. Therefore, the stress vector on principal planes is given by \vec{p} = \sigma_{p}\vec{n}\vec{p} = \sigma_{p}\vec{n} where \sigma_{p}\sigma_{p} is the magnitude of the stress vector, \vec{p}\vec{p} and \hat{n} = l\hat{i} + m\hat{j} + n\hat{k}\hat{n} = l\hat{i} + m\hat{j} + n\hat{k} is the unit normal to a principal plane. By projecting \vec{p}\vec{p} along each axis and substituting into \vec{p} = \vec{\tau_{ij}}\hat{n}\vec{p} = \vec{\tau_{ij}}\hat{n}, we arrive to the identity matrix:

section.simpara: This becomes an eigenvalue problem. A non-trivial solution for the direction cosines requires that the characteristics stress determinant vanish; therefore, we set this equal to zero.

This gives the characteristic equation: \sigma_{p}^{3} - I_{1}\sigma_{p}^{2} + I_{2}\sigma_{p} - I_{3} = 0\sigma_{p}^{3} - I_{1}\sigma_{p}^{2} + I_{2}\sigma_{p} - I_{3} = 0; wherein, {I_{1}, I_{2}, I_{3}}{I_{1}, I_{2}, I_{3}} are the stress invariants.

figure.title: In general, using Mohr’s Circle is not helpful for 3D analyses but can helpful to double check work.

textobject.phrase: mohrs circle for triaxial stress 220120 143146 EST

equation.title: Problem 1: The following describes the stress distribution in a body (in MPa). Determine the body force distribution required for equilibrium and the magnitude of its resultant at the point: (x, y, z) = (-10, 30, 60)~mm(x, y, z) = (-10, 30, 60)~mm.
equation.alt: \begin{split} \sigma_{x} &= x^{2} + 2y \\\ \sigma_{y} &= xy - y^{2}z \\\ \sigma_{z} &= x^{2} - z^{2} \\\ \tau_{xy} &= -xy^{2} + 1 \\\ \tau_{yz} &= 0 \\\ \tau_{xz} &= xz - 2x^{2}y \end{split}
equation.mathphrase: \begin{split} \sigma_{x} &= x^{2} + 2y \\\ \sigma_{y} &= xy - y^{2}z \\\ \sigma_{z} &= x^{2} - z^{2} \\\ \tau_{xy} &= -xy^{2} + 1 \\\ \tau_{yz} &= 0 \\\ \tau_{xz} &= xz - 2x^{2}y \end{split}

section.simpara: These forces are body, not surface forces; therefore, we are findings forces per volume.
section.informalexample:
First, we find the partials.
\begin{split} \frac{\sigma_{x}}{\partial x} &= 2x \\\ \frac{\sigma_{y}}{\partial y} &= z - 2yz \\\ \frac{\sigma_{z}}{\partial z} &= -2z \\\ \frac{\tau_{xy}}{\partial x} &= -y^{2} \\\ \frac{\tau_{xy}}{\partial y} &= -2xy \\\ \frac{\tau_{yz}}{\partial y} &= 0 \\\ \frac{\tau_{yz}}{\partial z} & = 0 \\\ \frac{\tau_{xz}}{\partial x} &= z - 4xy \\\ \frac{\tau_{xz}}{\partial z} &= x \end{split} \begin{split} \frac{\sigma_{x}}{\partial x} &= 2x \\\ \frac{\sigma_{y}}{\partial y} &= z - 2yz \\\ \frac{\sigma_{z}}{\partial z} &= -2z \\\ \frac{\tau_{xy}}{\partial x} &= -y^{2} \\\ \frac{\tau_{xy}}{\partial y} &= -2xy \\\ \frac{\tau_{yz}}{\partial y} &= 0 \\\ \frac{\tau_{yz}}{\partial z} & = 0 \\\ \frac{\tau_{xz}}{\partial x} &= z - 4xy \\\ \frac{\tau_{xz}}{\partial z} &= x \end{split}
Next, with these derivations and summing the forces in the xx-direction, we find: F_{x} := 2(-10) + (-2)(-10)(30) + (-10) + F_{x} = 0 \\ \implies F_{x} = 570~\frac{N}{m^{3}}F_{x} := 2(-10) + (-2)(-10)(30) + (-10) + F_{x} = 0 \\ \implies F_{x} = 570~\frac{N}{m^{3}} Similarly: F_{y} = 14.5~\frac{kN}{m^{3}}F_{y} = 14.5~\frac{kN}{m^{3}} and F_{z} = 50.8~\frac{N}{m^{3}}F_{z} = 50.8~\frac{N}{m^{3}}.
Problem 2: The stress components at a point in a plate are \sigma_{x} = 80~MPa\sigma_{x} = 80~MPa, \sigma_{y} = 60~MPa\sigma_{y} = 60~MPa, \sigma_{z} = \tau_{xy} = 20~MPa\sigma_{z} = \tau_{xy} = 20~MPa, \tau_{xz} = 40~MPa\tau_{xz} = 40~MPa, and \tau_{yz} = 10~MPa\tau_{yz} = 10~MPa. (a) Determine the stress vector on a plane normal to the vector <i, 2j, k><i, 2j, k>. (b) Determine the principal stresses \sigma_{1} \geq \sigma_{2} \geq \sigma_{3}\sigma_{1} \geq \sigma_{2} \geq \sigma_{3}. (c) Determine the maximum shear stress. (d) Determine the octahedral shear stress.
To find the solution vector, \vec{n}\vec{n}:
\begin{split} \vec{n} &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{i^{2} + j^{2} + k^{2}}}(\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} + \hat{k}) \\\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}(\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} + \hat{k}) \end{split} Find \vec{p}\vec{p} according to appropriate equations…​
Principal Stresses We find the stress invariants to be I_{1} = 160~MPaI_{1} = 160~MPa, I_{2} = 5500~MPa^{2}I_{2} = 5500~MPa^{2}, and I_{3} = 0I_{3} = 0. \therefore\therefore, we plug these into the characteristic, cubic equations. \sigma_{p}^{3} - 160\sigma_{p}^{2} + 5500\sigma_{p} - 0 = 0 \\ \implies \sigma_{p} = \{0, 110, 50\}~MPa\sigma_{p}^{3} - 160\sigma_{p}^{2} + 5500\sigma_{p} - 0 = 0 \\ \implies \sigma_{p} = \{0, 110, 50\}~MPa. We check that \sigma_{1} \geq \sigma_{2} \geq \sigma_{3}\sigma_{1} \geq \sigma_{2} \geq \sigma_{3} which maps \vec{\sigma_{p}}\vec{\sigma_{p}} to \{110, 50, 0\}~MPa\{110, 50, 0\}~MPa.
From these, we can draw Mohr’s Circle.
Therefore, \tau_{max} = 55~MPa\tau_{max} = 55~MPa.
example problem set 1 2 problem 2 mohrs circle 220125 140842 EST
Problem 3: The following stress array relative to axes (x, y, z)(x, y, z) is given where the stress components are in MPaMPa. (a) Determine the stress invariants of \mathbf{T}\mathbf{T}. (b) Consider a rotation of the (x, y)(x, y) axes by 45^{\circ}45^{\circ} counter-clockwise in the (x, y)(x, y) plane to form axes (x', y')(x', y'). Let the zz-axes and the z'z'-axis coincide. Calculate the stress components relative to the (x', y', z')(x', y', z') axes. (c) With the results of part (b), determine the stress invariants relative to axes (x', y', z')(x', y', z'), and show that they are the same as the invariants of part (a). \tau_{ij} = \begin{bmatrix}4 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 6 & 0 \\ 2 & 0 & 8\end{bmatrix}~MPa\tau_{ij} = \begin{bmatrix}4 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 6 & 0 \\ 2 & 0 & 8\end{bmatrix}~MPa.
Invariants of \mathbf{T}\mathbf{T}
\begin{split} I_{1} &= 18~MPa \\\ I_{2} &= 99~MPa^{2} \\\ I_{3} &= 160~MPa^{3} \end{split}
Finding the stress components in the new coordinate system .We must build the table of cosines.
x y z
x' \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} 0
y' \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} -\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} 0
z' 0 0 1
Therefore, the stress tensor in the new coordinate system can be found by: [\tau_{ij}'] = [T][\tau_{ij}][T]^{T}[\tau_{ij}'] = [T][\tau_{ij}][T]^{T}. This yields, [\tau_{ij}'] = \begin{bmatrix}6 & 1 & \sqrt{2} \\ 1 & 4 & -\sqrt{2} \\ \sqrt{2} & -\sqrt{2} & 8\end{bmatrix}~MPa[\tau_{ij}'] = \begin{bmatrix}6 & 1 & \sqrt{2} \\ 1 & 4 & -\sqrt{2} \\ \sqrt{2} & -\sqrt{2} & 8\end{bmatrix}~MPa.

important.title: Regarding codes in homeworks
important.simpara: Upload any codes used in solving the homework problems. Restrict coding language to MATLAB.

section.title: Strain, Deformation, and Mechanical Properties

formalpara.title: Introduction
formalpara.para: Most bodies undergo some amount of elastic deformation under some external loading.

listitem.simpara: A geometric quantity that measures the deformation of a body.

section.simpara: This is one of the most important topics in solid mechanics because strain quantifies the changes in geometry during deformation from applied stresses.

listitem.simpara: In a direction \hat{n}\hat{n}, this is defined as the change in length per unit length of the fibers oriented in the nn-direction.

section.simpara: In solid mechanics, if we consider the deformation of a prismatic bar, then we represent average strain as \epsilon_{\text{avg}} = \frac{L - L_{0}}{L_{0}} = \frac{\delta}{L_{0}}\epsilon_{\text{avg}} = \frac{L - L_{0}}{L_{0}} = \frac{\delta}{L_{0}}.

formalpara.title: Pure Shear
formalpara.para: Shear strain is allowed by the shear forces balancing each other out on each face of differential elements.

listitem.simpara: The change in angles between two originally perpendicular line segments.

question.simpara: Why are there two different notations for normal strain? — dk

answer.simpara: If you do not have enough information to perform the integral, then you assume the average strain.

formalpara.title: Tension Testing: Mechanical Properties of Materials
formalpara.para: This is most important test for us. Slowly applying axial loads unto a cylindrical bar, the specimen, the strain can be measure for some strain-rate. Typically, the yield point of a specimen is determined the 0.2%-offset Method.

qandaset.title: Brittle versus Ductile Materials and Elasticity versus Plasticity

question.simpara: How do we know the difference between brittle and ductile materials? — Dr. Lugo

answer.simpara: This distinction is subjective, but in general, ductile materials undergo much more plastic strain (absorb more energy) before failure than "brittle" materials. Typically, this defining limit is held as 5% strain.

section.simpara: If we unload the specimen before the applied stress exceeds the yield point, then the material will elastically return to its original length. This holds true to viscoelastic materials; however, "visco-" connotes some time-dependence, but, ultimately, the specimen does return to its original geometry.

formalpara.title: Linear Elasticity and Hooke’s Law
formalpara.para: Most engineering materials have an initially, linear elastic region on the stress-strain diagram. This linear relationship between stress and strain for a material in simple tension can be expressed by:

section.simpara: This constitutive relationship is to us what Newton’s Second Law of Motion is to physics.

formalpara.title: True Stress-Strain Curve
formalpara.para: This differs from engineering strain, which considers that the cross-sectional area remains constant, by considering that the cross-sectional area changes with changes in overall length.

section.simpara: In Advanced Mechanics of Materials, we consider only the elastic region; therefore, ss and \sigma\sigma are considered equivalent which is true until sufficient plastic deformation. ss and \sigma\sigma are related by:

listitem.simpara: True stress increases continuously until sufficient plastic strain allows for the material to begin necking.
When axial loads are applied to a member.

section.simpara: We must make key assumptions:

listitem.simpara: asdf

section.simpara: By these, we get an equilibrium equation: \delta = \frac{PL}{AE}\delta = \frac{PL}{AE}. If the member has regions of different cross-sectional areas and loads applied not only at the ends of the body, then the Law of Superposition can be applied to find total elongation: \delta = \sum\frac{PL}{AE}\delta = \sum\frac{PL}{AE}.

figure.title: Considering these two structures, we can solve the left-hand figure by summation of the forces to find the overall deformation. However, the right-hand figure is statically indeterminate.

section.simpara: Reactions for the left-hand can be calculated from equilibrium equations, but left-hand cannot be solved this way. We must also include compatibility equations.

listitem.simpara: Equilibrium equations: \sum F_{x} = R_{A} + R_{c}\sum F_{x} = R_{A} + R_{c}
Constitutive equations: \delta = \frac{PL}{AE}\delta = \frac{PL}{AE}
Compatibility equations: \delta_{T} = 0\delta_{T} = 0

figure.title: We can also use Law of Superposition. We temporarily remove one of the fixed points and consider each region of the body separately with constitutive equations that are coupled together with equilibrium and compatibility equations.

formalpara.title: Thermal Effects on Axial Deformation
formalpara.para: Considering a homogeneous bar \bar{AB}\bar{AB} of uniform cross-section on a smooth, horizontal surface, there is a change in length with change in temperature.

example.title: Example Problem Set: 2-1

figure.title: The rigid beam is supported by a pin at AA and wires \bar{BD}\bar{BD} and \bar{CE}\bar{CE}. If the load P on the beam causes the end CC to be displaced 10~mm10~mm downward, determine the normal strain developed in wires \bar{CE}\bar{CE} and \bar{BD}\bar{BD}.

example.simpara: We are given \delta_{c} = 10~mm\delta_{c} = 10~mm, and we want to find \epsilon_{BD}\epsilon_{BD} and \epsilon_{CE}\epsilon_{CE}. Using a Law of Similar Triangles:

The length of each cable is L = 4~mL = 4~m. To find \epsilon_{BD} = \frac{\delta_{B}}{L} = ${round(30/7/4000, 6)}~\frac{mm}{mm}\epsilon_{BD} = \frac{\delta_{B}}{L} = ${round(30/7/4000, 6)}~\frac{mm}{mm}. To find \epsilon_{CE} = \frac{\delta_{C}}{L} = ${round(10/4000}~\frac{mm}{mm}, 6)\epsilon_{CE} = \frac{\delta_{C}}{L} = ${round(10/4000}~\frac{mm}{mm}, 6).

figure.title: The 2014-T6 aluminum rod of \varnothing 20~mm\varnothing 20~mm is subjected to the uniform distributed axial load. Determine the displacement of end AA.

example.simpara: We are given d = 20~mmd = 20~mm and that the rod is 2014-T6 aluminum.
